column2: Faculty: we (instructional support staff) struggle to make ourselves available to you, yet so often you voice concern that you do not have enough support. How can we do a better job of reaching out to you when you need us?
I'd like to know more about the FIELD method

Much of the research on learning seems focused on helping students to master certain types of information and concepts. However, most of the people in this room indicated that the most important things about learning have to do with engagement, passion, and
Is 'students retain 90% of what they do, 50% of what they hear and 10% of what they see' a myth?
Some great online courses in the sciences have interactive exercises and simulations. What are potential advantages of online courses in the social sciences and humanities? -Hauke
what is the appropriate unit of time across which to measure change in student or teacher efficiency? Semester? 4 years? Lifetime?

isn't part of the drive to assess part of the structural transformation of the faculty from learned professionals to technically specialized employees?
When we define learning as delayed recall, how does this limit our investigation of quality teaching?
How do we gather and share rich data about learning that is not easily quantifiable?

How can faculty & staff collaborate to create an environment that promotes a 'virtuous circle' where learning and the application of knowledge & skills are reinforced both inside & outside the classroom?

How do we consider or factor the way assessments are designed and courses are structured in how well learners learn and retain concepts. Isn't successive relearning trying to address problems that we have created because of how we choose to teach?
How do you manage students' feelings of entitlement to their preferred learning styles when they may be at odds with your approach to teaching?
Pipeline for translating ed research into practice? Models that stress accessibility rather than profit.
Is there any data showing positive or negative impacts of courses that make extensive use of activity based learning
How do we differentiate learning from memorization? Isn't successive relearning just memorization?

With the advent of MOOCs (massive open on-line course) such as those offered by EdX, what would be the best way to leverage these large communities of students to inform and drive teaching methods? Example: It may be possible to implement semi-randomized studies of teaching methods which are not adverse to students (maintain 'fairness' in grading) but which would not only be able to which teaching methods perform better than others (e.g., short teaching section immediately followed by short problem vs. long, in-depth teaching section followed by longer exercises at a later date) but also to develop mechanisms to differentiate between which methods are best suited for which students. This may be important since it seem likely that some students will be better helped by one method while others by another, and it may be possible to create a more personal or individually optimized learning experience at relatively low per-student cost. - 132d418bd5a4de28b4e5357613b5ad8857b5480139613e9f2b8e5636
